conversation.message: That is an excellent question and central to our pedagogical approach. We integrate the development of executive function skills—including working memory, cognitive flexibility, and inhibitory control—directly into our daily activities. For example, during complex block-building tasks or cooperative games, children practice planning, sequencing steps, and managing frustration (self-regulation). We also utilize specific curriculum components that focus on problem-solving narratives and 'stop and think' techniques before acting. This structured environment ensures a strong foundation for future academic success. Are there specific aspects of self-regulation you are most interested in seeing demonstrated?
